newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu won't commit to date on Hebron.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu won't commit to date on Hebron.

text.p: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu refused after meeting Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat on Wednesday to give any date for Israel's long-delayed troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron.
He told a news conference the issue would be discussed in future negotiations with the Palestinians.
Asked for a specific date for the Hebron redeployment and other troop withdrawals, Netanyahu said: "They'll be discussed as I said in the steering committees."
"I have nothing to add but to state that we will continue to negotiate and to coordinate in all efforts, by all means," Arafat told the reporters when asked about Hebron.

A Palestinian official said that in the steering committee they would only discuss implementation -- and not modification -- of the agreement to redeploy in Hebron, the last of seven West Bank cities due to have been handed over to Palestinians under a 1995 peace deal expanding self-rule.
The Hebron redeployment had been delayed since March following a spate of Islamic suicide bombings killed 59 people. Hebron, where 400 Jews live among 100,000 Arabs, is a flashpoint of tensions.
